Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Novel Anode Formulation for Improving Cycle Life of Lithium Metal Batteries
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project will develop key components of a next-generation lithium metal battery that greatly increases both energy density and safety compared to the best lithium-ion batteries. Such a technology has the potential to deliver significant societal value by improving the state-of-the-art in battery markets such as implantable medical devices, electrified flight, electric vehicles, and many others. In fact, improvements just in medical device batteries may cause a step-change improvement in device design and delivery of healthcare that could save tens of thousands of lives annually. This project will increase opportunities for US-based manufacturing and create jobs by leveraging existing domestic prototyping and manufacturing capabilities around the country. Once material and process costs come down with scale, this technology can also help to expedite mass-market adoption of electric vehicles, consumer electronics, wearables, and other portable devices. The proposed technology may eventually allow for the widespread adoption of sustainable electrified transportation, reduce US dependence on foreign oil, significantly reduce carbon emissions related to transportation, and build an edge for US-based battery R&D and manufacturing.


The project addresses the key unmet challenge for next-generation battery chemistries based on lithium metal: highly reversible cycling (> 500 cycles with lithium plating efficiency > 99.7%) with high charging current density (> 1 mA/cm^2). The objective of the proposed R&D is to prove out a concept around novel metallic anode formulation that can enable unprecedented cycle life, lithium plating efficiency, and charging rate. Existing cell prototypes with pure lithium metal anodes have already demonstrated stable cycling and high specific energy at lower rates. However, inadequate lithium plating efficiency at high charging rates limits the cycle life that can be achieved in a commercial cell. Phase I research efforts will focus on two main objectives: (i) improve reversibility and efficiency of the metallic anode at high charge rates compared to pure lithium metal, and (ii) demonstrate the performance benefits in a coin cell with commercially attractive design parameters that delivers 500 cycles with minimal lithium loss at a high rate. The ultimate goal of the Phase I research is to develop a high-performance lab prototype, based on an optimized electrolyte and commercial cell components, that will provide proof of feasibility for rapid commercialization in the target market.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The performance of lithium-ion batteries has plateaued. In the decades since their invention, the technology has been so optimized that performance is approaching the fundamental limits of the materials that comprise the batteries. Furthermore, lithium-ion batteries require often costly, complicated, and heavy safety engineering to prevent the flammable organic solvents from bursting into flame or exploding. Significant economic and social opportunity lies with electronic devices that demand better batteries before they can be successfully commercialized. The adoption of electric vehicles generally (whether micro, mild, full HEV, PHEV, or EV) is hindered by the slow pace of improvements in battery technology. Specifically, improvements in cell specific energy (Wh/kg), energy density (Wh/L), and safety – all of which can dramatically lower cost per kWh at the pack level – will be essential to enabling mass market penetration of EVs.

Ultimately, improved battery technology is indispensable in electric vehicles and grid-scale storage if the United States is to realize the benefits to national security and reduction of carbon emissions that come of energy independence. The economic opportunity is immense; the global lithium-ion battery market is already approaching $50 billion per year, and it continues to grow with the continued adoption of EVs.

The batteries that will enable the technological future must go beyond lithium-ion, beginning with replacing the constituent materials. Cuberg is a world leader in the design of high-energy, extremely safe batteries, based on lithium metal anodes paired with a fundamentally new nonflammable electrolyte.

Cuberg dramatically improved battery lifetime over the course of this NSF Phase I project. The lifetime of a battery is the number of times it can be charged and discharged before it needs to be replaced. This was accomplished purely through electrolyte modifications, preserving Cuberg’s unique ability to build high energy lithium metal cells with standard lithium-ion production equipment. This focus on ease of production sets Cuberg far apart from the competition and results in better batteries sooner.

Part of the electrolyte modification was the incorporation of new additives into the electrolyte and optimization of their concentrations. These chemicals react when in contact with the lithium metal anode. The chemical, physical and mechanical properties of the layer spontaneously formed between the anode and the electrolyte can be tuned by proper choice of these additives based on an understating of their reaction products.

Another significant part of the cycle life improvement came from the optimization of lithium salt formulation and concentration in Cuberg’s new electrolyte. Lithium salts are needed to give the electrolyte the ability to conduct lithium ions between the cathode and the anode. Both the type of lithium salt (i.e. the anion) and its concentration have a profound impact on cycle life, as well as the rate at which the battery can be charged and discharged.

The result of the work funded by this proposal was commercially attractive 5Ah pouch cells achieving high energy density and specific energy – nearly 350 Wh/kg with un-optimized cell construction – with over 150 cycles. Once the cell engineering and construction are optimized, this chemistry will deliver over 400 Wh/kg – a 50% improvement over state of the art lithium ion technology at 270 Wh/kg – with dramatically improved safety characteristics. These cells will be commercialized initially in the aviation, aerospace, defense, and medical device industries.
